ygData.subject: Re: Evolving Soft Robots with CPPNs (New Paper & Video)

Hi Derek, nice to see you back.  I think you raise a very interesting que=
stion about the degree of regularity in these creatures. Of course, I don't=
 speak for the authors but one thing I'm sure you also noticed is the compl=
etely disorganized and amorphous directly-encoded individual in figure 7.  =
Compared to that, it's clear even here the CPPNs are having a significant o=
rganizing effect on these overall morphologies.

Nevertheless, it's still a=
n interesting question why these creatures aren't even more regular, so I w=
anted to throw out a hypothesis:  It's speculation at this point, but I wou=
ld guess part of the effect seen here is the "objective paradox" caused by =
rewarding them only for walking farther.  That kind of very explicit object=
ive encourages piecewise kind of improvement, i.e. if I add some idiosyncra=
tic element to my body and it makes me just a bit faster, that element will=
 get rewarded and tacked on to my lineage forever.  In addition, if I disco=
ver some kind of overarching regularity like bilateral symmetry, it will no=
t be retained unless it immediately significantly improves my gait.   So I'=
d speculate that you'd see more regularity with some kind of behavioral and=
/or morphological diversity pressure (like novelty search, novelty search w=
ith local competition, or some kind of multiobjectivization like MOLE) rath=
er than just pushing only for faster and faster walkers, because diversity =
pressures can reward and hold onto overall changes in organization even if =
they don't immediately lead to improvements in ambulation.  Of course, the =
authors acknowledge this issue themselves in their discussion as well, so i=
t's clearly already on their minds, but certainly interesting to look at in=
 the future.

Best,

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek" <djames@..=
.> wrote:
>
> Congrats on the paper and the interest it's generated, Jeff. =
Cool stuff!
> I've been focused on game development for mobile the last few=
 years, but
> I'm dipping my feet back into evolutionary algorithms researc=
h lately.
> I'm also working on evolving virtual creatures (I'm using jMonk=
eyEngine
> for my 3D graphics/physics engine and it's working quite well), =
so this
> stuff has been on my mind a lot.
> I think using materials with d=
ifferent physical properties and a
> generative encoding are both significa=
nt steps in advancing this line of
> research. However, I have to admit bei=
ng a little disappointed at the
> types of morphologies that you evolved. T=
he 2D products of CPPNs often
> exhibit a high degree of symmetry. Maybe it=
's the camera angles on the
> videos, but I didn't see a very high degree o=
f symmetry in your
> phenotypes. You say your CPPN implementation used Gaus=
sian functions.
> Did you have many phenotypes that exhibited strong bilate=
ral symmetry?
> Most of the phenotypes you demo are very interesting, but t=
hey seem like
> very cobbled, amorphous body plans, rather than individuals=
 that exhibit
> a high degree of symmetry and modularity. In many cases, th=
ey also seem
> top-heavy, with quite a few extra voxels that don't seem to =
be
> contributing much to the locomotion strategy.
> In your paper I don't =
think you come right out and say it explicitly,
> but you seem to imply tha=
t your critters are more naturalistic than
> Sims' or work since then. The =
use of pliable elements does lend to a
> perception of naturalism, but to m=
e they honestly seem about as close to
> naturally-occurring organisms as m=
ost of Sims':
> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DJBgG_VSP7f8
> <http://www.=
youtube.com/watch?v=3DJBgG_VSP7f8>
> When I watch videos of his evolved mor=
phologies, especially swimmers,
> they subjectively seem like primitive org=
anisms, even though they're
> composed entirely of rigid body parts.
> I ho=
pe this isn't coming across as too negative...I do like the work and
> thin=
k it is a great contribution. But a discussion on some of these
> points mi=
ght be worthwhile.
> Best,Derek
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <=
jclune@> wrote:
> >
> > Hello all,
> >
> > I am pleased to announce a new p=
aper on evolving soft robots with
> CPPNs. In it we try to improve the comp=
lexity of evolved virtual
> organisms over what Karl Sims generated nearly =
20 years ago. What do you
> think: are we on track to do that? Have we alre=
ady? The video is the
> best way to judge.
> >
> > ----------Unplanned Last=
 Minute Upate --------------
> > I just found out that the video for the pa=
per is on the front page of
> Hacker News (I have no idea how they found it=
 so fast without any
> announcements).
> >
> > If you want to help out, ple=
ase go here and "up vote" us. You'll need
> to register, but that is painle=
ss. NOTE: you may have to scroll to the
> second or third page (hopefully n=
ot!).
> >
> > https://news.ycombinator.com/news
> >
> > Look for: "Bizarre =
Soft Robots Evolve to Run (ieee.org)"
> > ---------------------------------=
----------------------------
> >
> > Cite: Cheney N, MacCurdy R, Clune J, L=
ipson H (2013) Unshackling
> evolution: evolving soft robots with multiple =
materials and a powerful
> generative encoding. Proceedings of the Genetic =
and Evolutionary
> Computation Conference.
> >
> > Video: http://youtu.be/z=
9ptOeByLA4
> >
> > PDF: http://jeffclune.com/publications/2013_Softbots_GEC=
CO.pdf
> >
> > Abstract: In 1994 Karl Sims showed that computational evolut=
ion can
> produce interesting morphologies that resemble natural organisms.=

> Despite nearly two decades of work since, evolved morphologies are not
>=
 obviously more complex or natural, and the field seems to have hit a
> com=
plexity ceiling. One hypothesis for the lack of increased complexity
> is t=
hat most work, including Sims', evolves morphologies composed of
> rigid el=
ements, such as solid cubes and cylinders, limiting the design
> space. A s=
econd hypothesis is that the encodings of previous work have
> been overly =
regular, not allowing complex regularities with variation.
> Here we test b=
oth hypotheses by evolving soft robots with multiple
> materials and a powe=
rful generative encoding called a compositional
> pattern-producing network=
 (CPPN). Robots are selected for locomotion
> speed. We find that CPPNs evo=
lve faster robots than a direct encoding
> and that the CPPN morphologies a=
ppear more natural. We also find that
> locomotion performance increases as=
 more materials are added, that
> diversity of form and behavior can be inc=
reased with different cost
> functions without stifling performance, and th=
at organisms can be
> evolved at different levels of resolution.  These fin=
dings suggest the
> ability of generative soft-voxel systems to scale towar=
ds evolving a
> large diversity of complex, natural, multi-material creatur=
es. Our
> results suggest that future work that combines the evolution of
>=
 CPPN-encoded soft, multi-material robots with modern
> diversity-encouragi=
ng techniques could finally enable the creation of
> creatures far more com=
plex and interesting than those produced by Sims
> nearly twenty years ago.=

> >
> > As always, please let me know if you have any comments or question=
s!
> >
> > PS. Here is the IEEE Spectrum article that found the video:
> ht=
tp://spectrum.ieee.org/automaton/robotics/robotics-software/bizarre-so\
> f=
t-robots-evolve-to-run
> >
> >
> > Best regards,
> > Jeff Clune

istant Professor

> > University of Wyoming

ne@
